relation: Great for these types of students

USU is great for those who want to get away from home, but not too far. It is also great for those who want many social opportunities, and awesome academic opportunity. USU has a wide variety of very good academic programs, such as the Huntsman School of Business, which is a well-known and prestigious school in the Business world.

Live on-campus your first year, and room with a few people you don't know. It's a great way to make friends. I live currently live on-campus, and everyone in my building leaves their doors open when they are home, so you can just walk in and say hello, and very often, people hang out in the lounge or in the halls.

USU is very good about giving out scholarships and financial aid, and definitely has comparatively good tuition prices. Everything you pay in tuition and student fees comes back to you in the form of classes and school-provided services, such as a free Health Center (doctor's office), many gyms, and free bicycle rental.

There are always things going on around the USU campus. There are tons of clubs to join, and lots of fun things to do (such as a Humans vs. Zombies nerf war every semester!) You'll never be bored, and make lots of friends.

When you take a class at USU, you learn what you expected to learn from the class, and more. There are also many helpful services available, such as tutoring programs, group study rooms, computer labs, etc.

Aggie Ice Cream is like food for your soul. 26 flavors of goodness., 1118057=You can go hiking, ice skating indoors or outdoors in the winter, skiing (there is a fantastic ski resort in Logan Canyon about 45 minutes from campus), showshoeing, sledding, go to a show at the Ellen Eccles Theater, thrift shop, volunteer at numerous charitable organizations, attend free events and activities at the Logan Tabernacle (a community church/fine arts events center), shop at local businesses including antique book stores, organic markets, global trade gift shops, fashion boutiques, etc., you can take community classes, visit the local gardener's market from April to October, go yard-saleing, attend local religious services and events, get involved with the Deaf community, volunteer with our chapter of Special Olympics, spend time with the elderly, party at the White Owl (the only bar here that I know of), etc., 38363=Utah State University touts a friendly atmosphere, intimate campus, world-class research faculty and ready opportunities to work with them, and accessible professors. While the professors are readily available and glad to explain difficult courses during office hours, my professors explain concepts very poorly in class. Instruction seems to emphasize superficial examples and applications, and the deeper theory is rarely taught. My electrical engineering and statics lectures are 100% example, 0% theory, and the required textbooks only superficially explain things. The science professors are much better at explaining theory, but still emphasize sample problems instead of symbolic exploration. However, learning opportunities outside of class are much better. Though only a freshman, I’ve been able to work with the university’s Microgravity Research Team from day one, so I’ve picked up a little heat transfer theory and have written ten pages of the team’s proposal for a 2011 experiment. Almost any faculty member will set you up in a research project if you ask them, or at least tell you what to study so that you can contribute as soon as possible. They are happy to accept volunteer lab workers. The USU library is an excellent learning environment. It has quiet zones, group study rooms, several large open computer labs and conversational study areas, and an excellent collection. Besides, it boasts a flood of natural light in the daytime, so you don’t feel locked up and confined inside. Overall, I’d say USU is a pretty average learning environment. Although it is big here, you always feel like you are important and a part of the school. Tips for prospective students I live in some apartments down the street from the University campus and across the street from the Spectrum and the Stadium.
